author: illusiveab

author: Xzlk
body: Not even lying, this is the first day in my life where I’ve seen $ZBRA red. I know it’s been red before obviously but this is the first day I’ve seen it with own eyes. Kinda mad the streak was broken.

author: jtmarlinintern
body:
I am sure others have mentioned these already, no particular order

&#x200B;

You too can be a Stock market Genius - Joel Greenblatt

Common Stocks, Uncommon Profits - Phil Fischer

Midas Touch - John Train

Zebra in Lion Country- Ralph Wanger

One Up on Wall Street- Peter Lynch

Not a Value Book, but the Market Wizards and Also New Market Wizards are good reads about successful Traders and Managers i found enjoyable

author: cuchiplancheo
body:
> The fuck is ZEBRA

No fucking clue. But, found more info: [ZEBRA stands for Zero Extrinsic Back Ratio, a term coined by Liz and Jenny in their TastyTrade show.](https://optionstradingiq.com/the-comprehensive-guide-to-the-zebra-strategy/)

author: itachisasuked
body: A bit cautious don’t ever forget good house in Japan king loves music not only popcorn questions ready set talk under vet water yacht zebra.

author: ZeekLTK
body:
Writing the same thing for every question is probably the best way to do it though (assuming it's a word/phrase that you will easily remember but no one else would think of).

Just doing something like "banana" or "zebra" or whatever, then if anyone finds out any of your actual info they still won't be able to answer the security questions. "What's your first pet's name?" "Pizza" "Mother's maiden name?" "Pizza", "Song from wedding?" "Pizza". lol no one would ever "guess" that.

author: PapaCharlie9
body: LOL. ZEBRA and PMCC are not *better* for new traders who wouldn't know a back ratio from a back stroke. Inherently, any multi-leg options trade is going to be more complicated than a single leg trade. Simplicity is good for beginners.

author: FreeAdministration34
body:
I believe $PINS will be back to $75-$80 area, which is the area before last ER, very soon. Check the graph in May-June-July, it dropped to $54.5 and go over $80. Same thing is going to happen. I also put some side dishes, $AMAT, $MA, $ROKU.  
  
36500 shares of $PINS with avg cost of $57.18. Let we see our ride.

|Palantir|PLTR|3.82%|
|DraftKings|DKNG|3.61%|
|Shopify|SHOP|3.20%|
|Google|GOOG|3.06%|
|Micron|MU|2.79%|
|Chewy|CHWY|2.78%|
|Thermo Fischer|TMO|2.33%|
|Etsy|ETSY|2.27%|
|Applied Materials|AMAT|1.99%|
|AST Space Mobile|ASTS|1.53%|
|Various Warrants|PSFE/WS, ALIT/WS, APPHW|1.41%|
|Pinterest|PINS|1.40%|
|Beam Therapeutics|BEAM|1.16%|
|Nvidia|NVDA|0.86%|
|Abbott|ABBT|0.78%|

Would be curious to get some thoughts on my holdings.  


Just going through it and typing everything out I never realized I'm up to 27 holdings nowadays, basically got an ETF on my hands. But on the other hand they're all spread out amongst 4 accounts (Brokerage, PCRA/Roth 401k, HSA Brokerage, and Roth IRA).  


Would probably like to shed PINS and MU but will wait till maybe year end to re-evaluate. So far the only tickers I'm down on is my future growth stuff like SOFI, PSFE, MP (marginally), but I've got a 5+ year time horizon on these ones, and then PINS and MU round out the losers.

author: SofaKingStonked
body: Very familiar with Ichor and ultra clean and have respect for both companies. I personally went Amat and lrcx for my semi equipment plays a year ago but admittedly almost sold and rotated mid august into uctt which hindsight being 2020 I should have done lol

author: SofaKingStonked
body:
In order of expected returns;

Himx - their qoq growth numbers look like some companies yoy numbers. They do various things but mostly known for display ic’s. (I want to mention micron in this same breath but momentum seems against it so I’m more aggressively pursuing himx)

Indi - automotive infotainment asic semi company (also does other things but all automotive focused). Huge tier 1 backlog

Mrvl - my preferred 5G play

Amd - I’m investing in cloud in multiple ways and see a lot of growth for Amd in server

Amat - earlier in the year I would have had asml above Amat as my top semi equipment company but they’ve run really hard and fast ytd so I feel Amat is a better value with lrcx a close second.

Cree I like for their rf products and SiC wafer technology but my small position is not growing until they drop the led business officially.

author: HTML_lovin
body: AMAT.

author: FreeAdministration34
body:
I believe $PINS will be back to $75-$80 area, which is the area before last ER, very soon. Check the graph in May-June-July, it dropped to $54.5 and go over $80. Same thing is going to happen. I also put some side dishes, $AMAT, $MA, $ROKU.  
  
36500 shares of $PINS with avg cost of $57.18. Let we see our ride.

author: buckster3257
body: I was invested in applied materials for a while but they seemed to have peaked in April and haven’t really done shit since then which is surprising considering how long this chip shortage has gone on for I would imagine their demand is through the roof

author: msnf
body:
I agree a basket approach is a good idea here, but I don't want to pay 0.3-0 4% ER when I can track the industry close enough with a few individual stocks. Currently own:

AMAT, AMD, ASML, LRCX, NVDA, MU, TSM as well as smaller players AMKR, ASX, UCTT with several others on my watchlist. Also, with the A-series and M-series chips AAPL is also a semiconductor company.

author: wildinterior
body: AMAT, LRCX

author: balance007
body:
KLAC- competitor to AMAT but much better

AVGO- solid PE and dividend, great CEO

QCOM- monopoly in 5g

SWKS- picking up the scraps from QCOM

SKYT- small cap foundry play could be big with bringing back semi production to USA

author: ClimbAndMaintain0116
body:
ASML average over the last 5 years: 150% per year
AMAT average over the last 5 years: 75% per year
NVDA average over the last 5 years: 287%

AMD average over the last 5 years: 340% per year


Like I said…zoom out. You’re on the short sighted train.

author: smokeyjay
body:
I own LRCX.  Most recent added more at 600.  Sold off my TSM to consolidate my stock portfolio.

I think AMAT & KLAC are also good buys.  ASML is a good company but richly valued imo.

Honestly a sector ETF might work for most ppl.  These are long term holds and not really WSB material.  I don't know how I feel about any positive short term trends - the whole world knows about chip shortages.

author: puregoblinvomit
body: Yes! LRCX and AMAT have a huge growing business in their legacy 150nm and above semi equipment groups (what AMAT calls ICAPs) these are the chips that auto makers and tons of other companies are missing right now. The semi equipment makers will be the winners in the end as fabs and foundries are all localized around the globe!

author: apophisdagod
body: Can't go wrong with AMAT or LRCX they both make chip making machines along with touch screen machines etc. I work for a company that supplies both of them and we can't keep up with the orders. AMAT actually offered to buy the company to just make parts for them. So naturally I am in AMAT.

author: tyrusrex
body: I've had etrade since my first job, since I was given a small stock vestmant for working with applied materials (Worth about $6k then about $13k now.)  it was through etrade that handled the stock, I've was mostly satisified but have become majorly dissatisfied.  They completely dropped the ball in giving me notifications.  I'm one of the GME/AMC cultists, and there were a few really important stock votes, which I was never notified about even after I complained and beg and pleaded that they notify me of upcoming votes.  They failed every time.  So as soon as I can, I plan to move to Fidelity or another brokerage,

body:
Started in April.  Have an stocks account up 24% and ETF account up 7%.

The stocks account was down by mid July made big losses on meme stocks(clov, clne, bb, mmed, ride, few other turds).

Currently I’m about 1/3 steel(+15ish%), 1/3 shipping(+60ish%), and 1/3 other assorted(cnr, net, panw, amat).

Although stocks are boring, up around 100% on shipping options and down around 75% on steel and meme options.
